Review:
Maker: Weissbierbrauerei G. Schneider & Sohn, Kelheim, Germany ***
Beer: Schneider Weisse Tap 5 Meine Hopfenweisse (bottled, unfiltered, 500ml) ***
Style: Weizenbock (Imperial Cloudy German Wheat) ***
ALC.VOL.: 8.2% ***

Colour: Hazy deep orange, with a huge, frothy off-white head. ***
Nose: Potent mix of overripe banana, sour citrus and clove. Yeast. ***
Texture: Full body, hardly watery. Modest carbonation. ***
Taste: Fruity at the start: a whole fruit basket of banana, pear, kiwi, melon, with a citric note on top. Alcoholic, too - and increasingly so towards the middle, with banana now dominating the fruit front. Finish is caramel, banana, some lemon, yeast. After taste of moldy banana, caramel. ***

Impressions: Impressive, highly drinkable strong cloudy wheat that blends fruit flavors, hops and the inevitable alcoholic note surprisingly smoothly. A particular recommendation for the friends of the Bavarian "banana wheat" style.

Review: Belgium’s most popular ’dubbel’, made under license from the Leffe abbey since the fifties but fallen into the clutches of AB InBev (then Interbrew) through a history of brewery acquisitions, as there have been many in 20th-century Belgian beer culture. It’s all over the place here, and in the absence of anything better, I have tasted this often from 33 cl bottle and from tap. For this rating, I pour it from a 50 cl can - which I suspect is a packing aimed at alcoholics, or in any way not the most flattering packing for an abbey beer. Medium thick and thinning but more or less stable, lacing, dense, light beige head over a deep red brown, cristal clear beer with almost no visible fizz. Aroma has that off-putting cooked pasteurization dominance as expected from the brand, lots of artificial caramel, iron (even dominating initially), freshly cut grass, cardboard, nutmeg powder, dry cocoa powder, liquorice, raw cauliflower, biscuit, cooked corn, coffee with milk, dried leaves, old cookies. Taste begins with a candied but one-dimensional and bland fruity sweetness, simple and straightforward, with minerally carbonation effect, lots of artificial caramel, vague nutty malts in the background but mostly pale maltiness as in a bland standard lager, sweetish, cornish, very metallic with a slick and actually rather thin mouthfeel, some roasted maltiness in the end but low hop bitterness, somewhat watery. I am happy to buy the rumour that this is actually a pimped lager nowadays - I get practically no fruity esters when smelling this, it has the smell and feel of a straightforward Dunkel - and not even a good one. In any case: this is just as bland as I had expected it to be, even under objective analysis. I stubbornly refuse to understand why people still seem to like this and why it is rated so high on this site. This is an off-putting, industrial strong Euro lager in disguise, if you ask me.  The mere fact that I have a principle of not wasting anything consumable kept me from pouring it down the drain.  Never liked it, never will.

Review:
355mL bottle from Beer Exchange. 2016 vintage 12.4%
And so here we are IMPERIAL STOUT #100
Some people make occasions for such things - in this case, the beer is the occasion.
Been a rather odd lead up - weather turned grey, heavens open up with howling winds, and I found a gosling in a trough half dead that I’m currently nursing back to health - it’s times like these you need something to take your mind off the world outside...
A viscous obsidian liquid is poured from the body - thick, like sump oil. An espresso-like dark tan creamer rises up & holds; taking its sweet ass time to drop down into a dense cap & painting the glass with cappuccino-like stains in its wake.
There’s an assault to the olfactory upfront - heavy on the bourbon undoubtedly, like cracking open a good bottle of Bakers - in itself complex with layers of vanilla, and charcoal, and sour mash grains. That combines with rich liqueur-like coffee, or maybe slow drip? Has a good deep cocoa note about it too, and burnt, almost blackened sugar.
Mouthfeel is what gets me first - this is not nearly as rich as most beers of this strength - quite well attenuated, dry, rather boozy, warm, get some woody tannin in there - very reminiscent of a swig of good Bourbon - that smoothness, yet dryness.
Palate doesn’t quite deliver what the nose promises, but it’s bloody nice! Bourbon up the wazoo - charred wood, sour mash twang, vanilla, toast, sort of overly ripe apricot, lots of wood! like massively. Chocolate, dark, coffee, strong, sugar, dark & strong & kinda burnt with burnt raisiny notes, smoky but not in a conventional manner. Smoooth finish, yet there’s a sort of acrid coffee & woody bitterness that counterpoints everything, sort of spurring you on as you take the journey.
This is spectacular! And it must be said, I’m not a huge Bourbon fan (single malt Scotch fan), but the execution & intensity here is second to none!

Review: There are beer trades and then there are gifts from God. The box from BeerAdvocate CRJMellor that included this Founders Breakfast Stout surely will rank among the divine gifts category. The beer came in a 12 oz. brown bottle with an artful label. Pouring this beer turned my pint glass into a black hole through which no light could escape. Even holding the glass an inch from a 100 watt bulb revealed nothing about the interior. The head was dark brown and thick, and left gobs of clumpy brown lace all round the walls of the glass. The aroma was laden with coffee, chocolate, and raisins. The dry and roasty taste was that of burnt oats, coffee, and chocolate. The mouthfeel was thick and chewy, and aftertaste a bit warm. Like eating a coffee cake (without too much sugar), this meal in a glass satisfied nearly all senses, and left me in a state of fulfillment, and in grateful appreciation of the art of brewing. What a fine brew. This proves that a good breakfast is the most important meal of the day.

Fantastic.  The one drawback to this beer, which keeps it from perfection, is the finish, which resembles cigarettes and their ashes. 6.4%ABV. Gueuze.    Poured out deep gold. 10ºSRM.    Nose has sour, acetic, lemon juice aromas. Subtler aromas include sour cherry, wood, and a florality suggesting marigolds and freesias.    Mouthfeel is bone dry, much like a prosecco or a champagne. Aggressive carbonation. You can certainly sip it, but don't try aerating it. Palate has wheat flour and hardtack. Overall, a really fine gueuze.    Goes on Favorites List!

It’s certainly not much of a beer but I guess that’s the idea, eh?  Lightweight corn rules the aroma and the taste. Notes of vanilla and coffee which linger on the tongue through the finish.  This is most definitely a snifter worthy stout.  October 19, 2011 - had a 2011 bottle celebrating the birth of my son.  I think this brew really starts to hit its stride 6 months after the release.  

2010 Bottle on November 20, 2010.  This is drinking even better now.  The beer has mellowed perfectly, perhaps a bit more creamy.

Dec. 16, 2010, a growler fill from Bowery Beer Room.  7-8 months and this brew is really good.  The coffee bite and booziness mellow, and the creaminess kicks up.  I am tasting more chocolate than I did a month ago.

330 ml white can with pull tab, available just about everywhere in HK. This one bought at DCH Food Mart in Sheung Shui.



Piss-like pale yellow colour; Virtually no head and residual white foam which fades in 10 seconds; No lacing and notable carbonation; Initially pungent smell of skunk and malt which thankfully died down very fast, plus light corn syrup and rice with hint of wet cardboard; Sweet taste of malt, rice, light corn syrup, hint of wet cardboard, and barely noticeable trace of grass; Light body with watery and syrupy palate; Hoppiness is skunk nose, otherwise almost undetectable and has no finish. Wet after taste, extremely easy to mouth.



Comments: Oh my goodness. My childhood memory of Tsingtao was quite decent, particularly the Export, which was very crisp, strong and tasty. Fast forward to present: this once reputable national brand has now become just another anonymous, lowly Asian macro released under a confusing array of abvs and degree Platos, almost all of them failed to impress. Back to this beer: its taste is considerably better than the all - cardboard Tsingtao 10°. Still, it’s a typical macros, with watery body, skunk, syrupy corn and rice, no hoppiness and after taste whatsoever. Tailor made for non-discerning consumers, very inoffensive, you can even consider it as decent by crappy macro standards. It could have been a nice substitution for Tsingtao 10° to cut down the chili heat of Sichuan cuisines. All being said and done, this is a tasting exercise went without a hitch and hopefully I don’t have to taste it again.

Review: Pilsener Urquell is one of those things people love to defend.  I would agree with those noble altruists that it is something like a fragile child in a world of more muscular, mature and intelligent beers.  I simply disagree about nurturing its confidence back using self-defeating lies.  It isn’t a pale lager, and has no business scratching desperately for mediocrity with that lot, but I don’t think it’s the paramount example of Pils primacy that particular members portray it as.  My notes on the beer are brief, as was the time I had with it, but they are not complimentary.  It was a clear and lucid beer (maybe more so than your averaged canned beer) with a frothy white head.  This bubbly top had an entertaining way of weaving a nice webby pattern of lace down the glass as I finished it which helped dispel some of the prejudice I was holding against it.  The smell was blander – a pretty simple base of mineral water with a strange component to it which I can only explain as giving the beer a “lurking” sense about it.  Not necessarily evil lurking like Jack the Ripper lurking, just… like lurking to sneak into the kitchen and eat the last slice of chocolate cake kind of lurking.  The taste seemed very fresh and dry but missing most of any flavor, opting to go in the other direction and actually taste bad.  Maybe I was drunk by this time but my notes read “Tastes like polluted rain water filtered through crypts”.  I don’t remember it being so offensive that I actually thought it tasted like damp necrotic flesh, just that it didn’t taste very good.  Any slew of industrial elements put together with some kind of mold or dust would do the job just fine.  I seriously wonder if my bottle was somehow tainted because the reviews seem to be a great deal more positive than I would have it.  To its credit I’ve heard how important it is to drink Pilsener Urquell fresh which rarely happens, so for now I’ll relegate myself to having purchased an aged bottle and make a sincere effort to try it again when the opportunity arises.

Smells of ground wheat with whisps of banana odor and a very slight ester.

TASTE: medium-low to low cereal flavour mixed with faint diacetyl. medium bitterness with a slight dry  and bitter finish. faint cardboard note. PALATE: medium-low body with moderate carbonation. OVERALL: this beer is not the same on the bottle.
label: Negative

Review: Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a weizen glass. Appearance is a hazy copper with a 1.5 finger width head with dark brown splotches from the yeast. Aroma reminds me of banana’s foster with its notes of brown sugar, bananas, vanilla, and rum. In the taste I get a fruity, raisiny sweetness that moves to an earthy, cooked banana overtone in the finish. The beer is a touch thinner in body than I would prefer, but that doesn’t put me off too much. Overall, this beer great. I wish it were more available around me.
label: Positive

Review: (500ml bottle from Spec’s on October 11, 2008) You’d think this was a dunkel from the looks of the bottle.  Pours a gorgeous orange with a solid, white frothy head and lacing that slides down the glass. Its aroma is of a serious German Weizenbock. Very sour, citric, and yeasty.  Smells like a brewery. Smells like fermented wheat! Its taste is of banana, cloves, and a hint of hops.  Smooth going down, almost makes you want to pucker. A finely crafted beer.

Review:
2/23/18
With A after an amazing day of Lancaster, KoP & Steakn’Shake. 

Poured from bottle. Hazy orange with a big fluffy white head. 

Nose is huge with lots of wheat, yeast and fruit. 

Taste is soft, creamy and sweet with wheaty flavors dominating over yeasty notes and dried fruit. Balanced and very flavorful with lots of sweetness and basically no bitterness. 

Palate is soft with great fluffy carbonation. Wheat flavors lingering. 

Overall, the first weizenbock I’ve had and everything a wheat beer should be. This is amazing!
